B. Marg, Bhavnagar 364002, India. Inorganic materials and Catalysis Division Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute CSIR G. B. Marg Bhavnagar 364002 India The current study focuses on the synthesis of an inexpensive, efficient, and cost-effective zirconium phosphate (ZrP) and its application in the one-step catalytic valorization of biomass-derived α-Pinene oxide (APO) into trans-Carveol (TC), which is used in the fragrance industry to produce essence oil. Amorphous zirconium phosphate (ZrP) with different P/Zr molar ratios (0.6–2.4) were synthesized using a simple (refluxing) method by controlling the concentration of dopant. The presence of phosphate groups was confirmed by FTIR and XPS analysis. The phosphate functionality provides the Brønsted acidic nature, and the acidity of the catalyst (ZrP3) is 0.9 mmol/g as measured by NH3-TPD analysis. Under optimized reaction conditions, the synthesized Brønsted acid catalyst (ZrP3) was used to valorize APO, resulting in complete conversion with 76% selectivity towards TC. The catalyst was recovered, activated, and reused numerous times with slight loss of activity or selectivity. Graphical abstract ASS performed experiments, analysis, wrote manuscript, DRN characterization of catalyst revised manuscript, KR-XPS analysis, AVB- Conceptualization, overall monitoring of project, funding and wrote manuscript Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zirconium phosphate Brønsted acid Bio-valorization α-Pinene oxide trans-Carveol 1 Introduction In recent years, the production of value-added fine chemicals, flavor, and fragrance from abundantly available biomass-derived chemicals such as terpenes and terpenoids have been a fascinating topic [1,2]. Terpenes are renewable feedstock that are safe and inexpensive raw materials for the production of specialty chemicals. In the present situation, where ever-increasing greenhouse gasses emission and fossil fuel depletion have drawn much attention to the development of chemo-catalysis and a greener route for the fulfillment of the rising needs towards a substitute valuable chemical and energy resources. Due to search alternatives, renewable is an outstanding fossil resource that can serve the cause. There are numerous biomasses readily available; terpenes, terpenoids, and vegetable oil are examples of hydrocarbon-rich biomass that are widely used to synthesize fine chemicals [3,4]. Terpenes and their oxides are the essential building blocks in the food flavor and fragrance industries. Turpentine derived from biomass is a significant by-product of the softwood industry [2,5,6]. These compounds are widely used in speciality chemicals or as reaction intermediates in the organic synthesis of drugs and insecticides [7]. The distillation of crude turpentine yields monoterpenes such as α-pinene, β-pinene, limonene, terpinolene and camphene [5]. Furthermore, epoxidation of monoterpenes to epoxides is important in organic transformation due to their ability to undergo numerous ring-opening reactions using an acidic or basic catalyst. Particularly, epoxidation of α-pinene yields APO, which can further isomerized in the presence of acid into a variety of high value-added chemicals for the fine industries, including campholenic aldehyde (CA), fencholenic aldehyde (FA), derivatives based pinane (trans-pinocarveol (TP) and isopinocamphone (IP)) and menthane (p-cymene (PCY), trans-carveol (TC) and trans-sobrerol (TS)) skeletons (Scheme. 1 ). It is well known that in the presence of an acidic or basic catalyst, three-membered cyclic epoxides are highly reactive towards the formation of more products rather than desired products. For selective isomerization reaction, mild reaction conditions were needed. Otherwise, it can give more than 200 products at or above 100 °C, hence achieving a selective product is a significant challenge for synthetic chemists [5,8]. To overcome these plausible side reactions and achieve the desired target molecule, an appropriate catalytic system must be designed [9]. It is well known that in the presence of Lewis acid, CA formation is favoured, whereas Brønsted acidic catalyst favours TC formation. Different Lewis acids properties bearing homogeneous, heterogeneous, and supported catalysts have been widely used for CA synthesis, whereas only a few reports exist on the chemoselective synthesis of TC by Brønsted acid catalyst [2,5,9,11-14]. CA derivatives represent the most efficient synthetic alternative for producing sandalwood odorants like Javanol, Pashminol, Dartanol, Brahmanol, Sandalmysore, Firsantol, Polysantol, Sandalore and Ebanol [10]. TC is a monoterpenoid alcohol with a spearmint odor that is essential and expensive chemicals industry as Valencia orange essence. It has also been shown to have anticancer activity in the mammary and other lump rodent models [9]. In addition, extensive research is being conducted to determine the high activity and selectivity of TC. For example, TC is selectively synthesized with the highest selectivity (73%) by the isomerization of APO over ceria or tin catalysts [14]. Many other solid acids have been tested in this reaction; for example, Stekrova et al. reported ceria doped mesoporous materials MCM-41/SBA-15 for TC Synthesis. Remarkably, TC maximum selectivity (41%) was observed [2]. Further, this group has synthesized H and Fe-modified zeolite beta catalysts to prepare TC from APO in a polar basic solvent N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) [13]. Da Silva Rocha et al. also reported APO isomerization over silica-supported heteropoly acid H3PW12O40 [15]. Other research groups were also working on selective TC synthesis. Shcherban et al. reported ZSM-5 based micro-mesoporous materials that were used for APO isomerization with lower selectivity for the TC [6]. TC was synthesized industrially using imprinted polystyrenes, gave a 45% yield [16]. It was well reported that the TC could be synthesized in the presence of Brønsted acid catalysts. As a result, there is a greater emphasis on the development of supported acid catalysts with higher Brønsted acidity. These literature suggests that the Brønsted-acidic functional materials can be synthesized using a variety of techniques such as co-precipitation, polymerization, immobilization methods [17–19]. Our group has also recently reported on metal-free phosphonate functionalized and sulphonated carbon for the isomerization of APO to TC (67–85%) in highly polar basic solvents such as DMF [5,9]. However, it faces the challenge of controlling the immobilization of phosphonate and sulphonate groups over a carbon as well as weaker CO-P and CO-S bond, which reduces recycling activity. ZrP has recently received increased attention in acid-catalyzed reactions due to its Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites [20–23]. As a result, the preparation of facile Zr-based solid acid catalyst by straightforward single-step reflux technique is not described for the valorization of APO. The transformation of biomass has been broadly explored over solid acid catalytic processes [24,25]. The objective of the present study is to develop a simple, low-cost, environmentally friendly, non-functionalized, noble-metal-free, and tunable Brønsted acid sites ZrP solid acid catalyst for the bio-valorization of APO into TC with high selectivity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Zirconium oxychlorideoctahydrate (96%), Phosphoric acid (85%) were purchased from S. D. Fine Chemicals. α-pinene oxide (95%), Dimethyl acetamide (99%) was purchased from TCI Chemicals, India. Dimethylformamide (99%), Dimethyl sulfoxide (99%), Xylene (99%), Toluene (99%) from SRL, Silica gel (100–200 mesh) for column chromatography from Qualigens India. All the chemicals were used as received without further purification. De-ionized water with a resistivity of 18 MΩ was used. 2.2 Preparation of ZrP The reported procedure was used to prepare ZrP [26] ZrOCl2·8H2O (2 g) was heated at reflux temperature with 20 mL of 0.6/1.2/2.4 M H3PO4 for 24 h. The white precipitate was cooled to room temperature, and it was filtered, washed with plentiful amounts of de-ionized water till it was chloride-free and the pH of the filtrate was neutral. The final products were identified as ZrP1 (0.6 M), ZrP2 (1.2 M), and ZrP3 (2.4 M), respectively. The solid white cake was then collected and dried in a hot air oven at 100 °C for 24 h. The fine grounded powder was calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in air and used as a catalyst without further activation. 2.3 Materials characterizations The structural characterization studies of the catalyst were carried out by different physicochemical methods. The XRD analysis was carried out using Philips X'pert MPD system for powder X-ray Diffractometer. The black powder obtained was scanned in the range of 10–80° using CuKα radiation of 1.54 wavelength with a Ni filter. The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping and morphology of the catalyst were determined using a JEOL JSM 7100F field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). The synthesized catalyst was dispersed in isopropyl alcohol by sonication and was drop cast on a brass stub. The stub was dried under a vacuum and used for analysis. A transmission electron microscope (TEM) (JEOL JEM 2100) was used to analyze the size and shape of the particles. The samples were loaded on the TEM grid by dispersing it in isopropyl alcohol using ultrasonicator and then drop-casting the suspension. This drop cast grid was dried in a vacuum desiccator before analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using Thermo Fisher Nexsa spectrometer using monochromatic Al Kα radiation with energy 1486.6 eV. The pass energy for Survey was set at 200 eV, and pass energy for the narrow scan was set at 50 eV. The dual-beam charge neutralization was used for both low-energy electrons and Ions. The sample surface is at 90° angle with the Axis of the input lens. Further, the individual core-level spectra by charge correction C1s at 284.8 eV was used as a standard. The peak fitting of the individual core-levels was done using Avantage software with the smart function for background correction. A Perkin-Elmer GX spectrophotometer was used for the Fourier-transform infrared spectrophotometry (FTIR) spectra using KBr pellets in the wavelength range of 400–4000 cm−1. The BET surface area, total pore volume, and average pore diameter were measured using the N2 adsorption-desorption method using ASAP 2010 Micromeritics, USA, at -[33]196 °C after degassing the sample under vacuum (10−2 Torr) at 300 °C for 6 h. The surface area was determined using the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) equation. Pore size distributions were determined using the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) model of cylindrical pore approximation. The acidity of the catalyst was measured using NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) on Micromeritics Auto-Chem 2920 instrument. In a typical measurement, about 0.1 g of the powdered sample was placed in a quartz U-tube and degassed at 150 °C for 1 h in helium at a flow rate of 40 mL/min. After cooling to 100 °C, the gas was changed to NH3 treated at the same temperature for 1 h. The gas was switched to helium at the same temperature and held at this temperature for 1 h. After this, the TPD was performed at 10 °C/min up to 550 °C. A thermal conductivity detector was used for the desorbed NH3 quantification. 2.4 Catalytic activity of ZrP as solid Brønsted acid catalyst As synthesized solid Brønsted acid catalyst (ZrP) was utilized in the valorization of APO. In a typical isomerization reaction, a 50 mL borosilicate glass tube was charged with 3.28 mmol of APO, the desired amount of the catalyst, and 2 mL of solvent. The glass tube was immersed in an oil bath and heated to desired temperature (80–160 °C) and time with a stirring speed of 600 rpm. After completing the reaction, it was cooled to room temperature. At different time intervals, the samples were withdrawn to monitor the reaction's progress by GC and GCMS. The used ZrP catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation, washed with methanol 3 times (10 mL each time), then dried at 80 °C in a hot air oven before being reused for the next cycle. The primary product was isolated by column chromatography. Pale yellow color, the sticky liquid was found. The pure product was characterized by GC–MS, 1H and 13C NMR. To see the structural and configurational change in the recycled catalyst was characterized with different techniques like SEM-EDAX and XPS. In addition, the synthesis and activity were replicated three times to check the reproducibility of the catalyst. Conversion and selectivity were obtained by gas chromatography (Agilent GC, 7890B) equipped with an HP-5 capillary column of 30 × 0.250 mm × 0.25 μm dimension and an FID detector and Shimadzu, GC–MS QP 2010, Japan. To investigate the catalytic activity of the different materials Turn Over Number (TON) and Turn Over frequency (TOF) value is required. T O N = m o l e s o f t r a n s c a r v e o l p r o d u c e d a m o u n t o f a c i d s i t e s o n s u r f a c e o f t h e c a t a l y s t T O F = m o l e s o f t r a n s c a r v e o l p r o d u c e d a m o u n t o f a c i d s i t e s o n s u r f a c e o f t h e c a t a l y s t x T i m e 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of ZrP Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectra of ZrP, which show a strong and broad peak cantered at 3433 cm−1 could be attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of -OH, which are the asymmetric stretching vibration of the water molecules, from hydrogen bonding in it [5,27] and the distinctive band around 1624 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric bending vibrations of hydroxyl groups caused by the deformation of water molecules. The strong sharp peak at 1103 cm−1 corresponds to the O-P symmetrical stretching vibrations peak of the -PO4 group. The intense bands at 520 cm−1 correspond to distortions modes of -PO4. The weak absorption band around 756 cm−1 corresponds to the P − O − P deforming vibration, signifying the presence of the polyphosphate groups [28,29]. The as-synthesized ZrP3 catalyst was also characterized by an electron diffraction pattern (XRD), which suggests the amorphous nature of the material because of its poor crystallinity. (See SI Figure S1). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to characterize the morphology of the prepared ZrP3 material (SEM) Fig. SI 3 depicts the SEM images of synthesized ZrP3 calcined at 600 °C for 4 h. Synthesized ZrP3 displays the aggregate of the small particle with non-uniform morphology (Figure SI 2a-d). Crystalline particles had aggregated to form sheets (Figure S2). The magnified image of ZrP3 reveals that the large microcrystals are built with small 100–200 nm nanocrystals. Furthermore, the corresponding elemental mappings of the ZrP3 material show that these (Zr, P, and O) major constituents and all have displayed homogeneous concentration (Fig. 1 e), revealing the uniform distribution in the zirconium phosphate surface (Fig. 2 c-e). In addition, the elemental composition of the ZrP catalyst was further analyzed by SEM-EDAX, which revealed 15.71, 30.71 wt.% of P and Zr (Fig. 2f). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to examine the topography of ZrP3 at the nano level as well as elemental distribution was inspected. Figures S3a confirm the aggregated topography of ZrP, which is consistent with the SEM morphology discussed previously. The high-resolution TEM image confirms that 50–100 nm size crystals built the aggregated morphology (Fig. 3 a-b). The electron diffraction pattern (EDS) measurements of the catalyst revealed Zr, P, and O, in the absence of contaminant elements. The amorphous nature of the material is suggested by SEM images which is consistent with the XRD spectra. Figure S4a also depicts the elemental mapping of P, Zr, and O elements obtained from the STEM micrograph. It demonstrates the uniform distribution of these elements throughout the material. Figure S4b presents TEM-EDX of ZrP3 that further confirms the presence of Zr, P, and O elements in the material. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was used to inspect the detailed evidence for chemical atmosphere and bonding in ZrP3 (Fig. 4 ). The complete survey spectrum of the ZrP3 material is in the range of 0–1300 eV (Fig. 4a). The individual core-level spectra were charge correction made using C1s at 284.8 eV. The survey analysis confirmed the distinctive peaks for the presence of P, O, and Zr elements in ZrP3. To study the oxidation states of various elements existing in ZrP3, the XPS spectra were recorded, independently, for these elements. The high-resolution spectrum of Zr 3d is depicted in Fig. 4b. two peaks found at 183.0 eV for Zr 3d5/2 and 185.3 eV for Zr 3d3/2, which were the distinctive peak of Zr4+ in ZrP3 [30,31]. In addition, the high-resolution spectra of O 1 s represent only a single broad peak that can be deconvoluted into four peaks cantered at 531.07 eV corresponds to the oxygen present as Zr-O-Zr, and the peak centered at 532.18 eV was attributed to the Zr-OH on the material surface of the ZrP3. While another peak at 531.53 and 532.76 eV corresponds to the for Zr-O-P and P-O-H, respectively, confirming the introduction of phosphorus (Fig. 4c) [9,29,30]. Furthermore, deconvolution of the P 2p shown (Fig. 4d) shows one broad, intense peak which corresponds to the phosphorous in the material that existed in a P + 5 oxidation state [29–31]. The existence of Zr-O-P and P-O-H recommends that the material has basic bridging “O” sites and acidic sites (Brönsted acidic sites due to P-O-H groups). Furthermore, the ZrP3 materials corresponding XPS elemental mapping shows that these (Zr, P, and O) as significant constituents all displayed homogeneous deposition on the surface. The catalyst was analyzed by the snap map technique, which involved scanning with respect to the 100 µm X-ray spots. For mapping, an area (1 × 1 mm) on the ZrP surface was chosen Fig. 4.e shows Zr3d (red), P2p (blue), O1s (green) elements in various colours. However, the principal component analysis (PCA) is useful for both the survey and high-resolution data of each element and shows that two components are present in P 2p (See SI S4–5) [31,32]. In addition, NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) technique, was used for the acidic properties of the ZrP catalyst. The NH3-TPD profiles of the ZrP catalyst are shown in Fig. 5 . The relative populations of ammonia adsorbed on the week and strong sites could be determined through peak deconvolutions, as given in SI Fig. S6, and acidity of catalyst by deconvolution was tabulated in SI Table 1 . From Fig. 5 it seems that the presence of phosphate ions in ZrP caused a substantial increase in the intensity of NH3 desorption peak when PO4/Zr ratio was increased from 0.6 to 2.4 M. This clearly says that phosphate ions contribute to the formation of acid sites. The total acidity of ZrP catalyst determined from NH3 desorption is summarized in Fig. 5 and Table, which show the acidity increase with increasing concentrations of phosphorus content as follows ZrP1<ZrP2< ZrP3. In addition, the acidity of these catalysts is nearly the same as earlier reported articles [33–35]. The Raman spectra (See SI Fig. S6) show a shift of the P-O vibration from 1084 cm−1. The surface area (BET) of the ZrP3 catalysts was 23.11 m2/g. The BJH adsorption cumulative pore volume of ZrP3 catalysts was found to be 1.08 cm3/g, and the BJH desorption average pore width was 115.45 Å (See SI Fig. S8). 3.2 Catalytic activity In the presence of Lewis acid or Brønsted acid catalyst, isomerization of APO may produce a variety of chemicals such as campholenic or fencholenic aldehyde, trans-carveol, trans-sobrerol, pinol, p-cymene, trans- isopinocamphone and trans-pinocarveol, etc. (Scheme 1) depending upon the reaction parameters and acid used in the reaction [5]. The ZrP is known auspicious acid catalyst for various acid-catalysis owing to their reliable acidic properties. However, the modification in the action of individual material catalysts used for the bio-valorization of APO, on the other hand, may be described in relation to loading in catalyst different types of material used for support for this study. The catalytic activity of Zr/P catalysts synthesized with varied Zr/P mole ratios was studied for isomerization of APO. ZrP3 gave the highest conversion of APO into TC in N, N Dimethylacetamide (DMA) among synthesized zirconium phosphates, with a TOF of 10.6 h − 1 (Table 1). Although the order of ZrP1 > ZrP2 > ZrP3 with (30.28 > 11.17 > 10.6) TOF h − 1 conversion of APO was lower in ZrP1 and ZrP2 due to a lower amount of acidic sites present in the catalyst. The conversion of APO was found directly proportional to the acidity of the catalysts. Hence, the optimization studies such as temperature, catalyst amount, time, solvents, and catalyst reusability were explored with ZrP3 as the catalyst. In addition, the effect of reaction temperature on APO isomerization was examined. APO conversion influence when temperature increase from 100 to 160 °C APO conversion also increased from 10 to 100%, while selectivity of TC was nearly the same, it means it is a kinetically controlled product (Fig. 6 a) [35]. The highest selectivity of TC was observed when the reaction was performed at 160 °C; thus, this temperature was chosen for further optimization. The rise in temperature favours the deprotonation of both a substrate and solvent, resulting in the selective synthesis of TC. For further optimization, the effect of the catalyst amount (10−60 mg) (for 3.28 mmol of APO) was varied, demonstrating that the conversion of APO increases from 30 to 100% (Fig. 6b). An additional enhancement in catalyst amount decreases the selectivity of TC from 73 to 71% because of its mild acidity for this reaction isomerization increases when the acidic strength increases and p-cymene and trans-pinocarveol are the major side product obtained. In addition, the TC drop in selectivity due to the dehydration to equivalent cyclic alkene. Theoretically, DMA aids in the abstraction of the proton that is present nearby the hydroxyl group present in TC, to extract the H2O molecule (Fig. 6c) [36]. A further increase in catalyst amount (50 to 60 mg) did not affect APO conversion. As a result, 50 mg of catalyst was chosen for further studies. Furthermore, the effect of reaction time (1–5 h) displays that the APO conversion increases from 43 to 100% and marginal increases in the selectivity of TC from 69 to 73% were observed (Fig. 6c). The highest selectivity of TC was obtained when the reaction was carried out at 5 h, so this time was chosen for further studies. The role of solvent and product distribution in APO isomerization has been well documented in the literature, with DMA, DMF favouring the formation of TC [5,9,36]. All polar solvents promote the formation of TC and trans-sobrerol via intermediate p-Menthenic skeletal compounds, while non-polar solvents promote the formation of campholenic aldehyde [37–39]. The valorization of APO in presence of a non-polar solvent such as toluene and xylene results on a high selectivity towards CA with 41–75% conversion (Fig. 6d). However, it was seen that the polarity of solvent boosts the reaction path through 2° (Scheme 2 ). In the presence of a partially polar solvent such as acetone gives 43% conversion with 58% selectivity towards trans-sobrerol. Furthermore, previous studies have shown that the basicity of solvent has a significant impact on TC selective product synthesis [2,9,1,13,14]. As a result of these reports, we chose highly basic solvents like DMF, DMA and DMSO. Surprisingly, we got an almost complete conversion of APO by using these solvents. Nevertheless, DMSO, which has the highest polarity of all solvents has the lowest selectivity of TC due to having the potential for Lewis acidic character (+S-O-) formation, which results in other by-products. But in the case of DMF, we got high selectivity towards TC. In situ formation of DMF-H + due to abstraction of H + contributed to the reaction and catalyzed the reaction. The acidic catalyst (ZrP) was utilized for the protonation of solvent, which in turn form DMF-H +, catalyzed the reaction to give TC as the desired product. From this observation, we believe that the valorization of APO is truly influenced by the nature of the solvent, which contributes to the reaction mechanism pathways and synthesis of desired products. From the industrial perspective, the bio-valorization of APO was scaled up to 5 g scale using best reaction conditions, and the selectivity of TC was dropped to 69% from 76% with 100% conversion of APO confirmed by GC, GCMS (see SI Fig. S9–12) and 1H, 13C NMR (see SI Fig. S13–14). In addition, the drop in TC selectivity occurred due to the formation of high boiling point products being increased. These results were not surprising given that oligomerization of APO occurs with increasing concentration [15]. 3.3 Plausible reaction mechanism Keeping all the parametric variations and the previous work reports in mind, the plausible reaction mechanism of the ZrP catalyzed APO isomerization for the formation of the major and minor encountered products is proposed (Scheme 2). We discovered that the solvent (DMF) used in the reaction plays an important role through optimization studies. According to the previous report, the polarity and basicity of the solvent have a strong influence on the reaction [5,9]. Brønsted solid acid catalyst transfers the H + to the DMF solvent to give an intermediate DMF-H +. It is due to the solvent's basic nature that can abstract a proton from the catalyst. This DMF-H + transfers H + to the epoxide ring persuading the ring-opening and giving unstable carbocation intermediate. This carbocation intermediate (I) can donate a pair of electron from the same carbon-carbon σ bond to yield 2° cyclopentanic carbocation (II) intermediate and 3° carbocation intermediate (III). The formation of Campholenic aldehyde takes place due to the removal of hydrogen and CC bond breaking of 2° carbocation (II This 3° carbocation (III) undergoes 1, 2 hydrogen shifts to form a carveol product. In the presence of moisture 3° carbocation undergo hydrolysis and form trans-sobrerol. This can further undergo dehydration to form 2-methyl-5-(propan-2-ylidene) cyclohex-2-enol. p-Cymene is a product of the consequent conversion of the products with the p-menthenic structure. TPC or TPCV formation takes place by direct hydrogen shift of carbocation intermediate. The formation of the 3° carbocation (III) is thermodynamically stable, whereas the 2° carbocation (II) is kinetically stable. From the earlier report study, we interrelate that simultaneously selectivity towards TC increases with an increase in temperature (See Fig. 6). Therefore, the formation of the trans-sobrerol and TC is thermodynamically controlled. DMF is highly basic (pKa ∼0.5 for DMF-H +) and due to its properties, its abstracts H + from the catalyst to form CA results from the shifting of adjacent carbon followed by loss of proton atom from (III). As seen, solvent nature plays a crucial role in the catalytic path and product distribution. The highly polar aprotic and basic solvent helps in proton abstraction from the Brønsted acid catalyst, resulting in high selectivity towards TC and conversion of the APO. 3.4 Recyclability and leaching test of the catalyst Leaching and recycling tests were conducted as part of the stability and reusability study. A hot filtration test was performed to assess catalysts leaching. After 15 min completion reaction time, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture, and the reaction was restarted with the filtrate (See Fig. S15). Under the optimized conditions and with fresh catalyst, complete conversion of APO was achieved in 5 h with 76% selectivity towards TC. The result had no discernible effect on catalytic activity and remained stable until the fifth cycle. No noteworthy change was observed in the conversion of APO (See SI, Fig. S16). The elemental composition of the reused catalyst is retained even after the 5th cycle, which approves the constancy of the ZrP (Brønsted acid) nanocatalyst. Additionally, the reused catalyst was characterized by XPS and SEM-EDAX and compared with the properties of the virgin catalyst. The result showed that the catalyst was stable after the fifth cycle shown in SI, Fig. S17–18. 5 Conclusions A series of amorphous zirconium phosphate was successfully synthesized and characterized with various physicochemical methods. The ratio of P/Zr was precisely controlled through changing the concentration of precursors to make the best catalyst. Introducing phosphorus on Zr framework in the ZrP catalyst through Zr-O-P covalently anchoring, which improves the thermal stability of this catalyst. Valorization of APO, giving complete conversion with 76% selectivity towards TC by as-synthesized ZrP catalyst. The excellent catalytic activity of ZrP in said reactions was owing to the optimal 0.9 mmol/g Brønsted acidity and high adsorption of APO on ZrP. Compared with the fresh catalyst, no apparent decrement in the catalyst activity was seen until five cycles. This solid Brønsted acid ZrP catalyst can be used in the isomerization of APO and other acid-catalyzed reactions. However, this simple solid acid catalyst, signifying the synthesis of a significant category of fine chemicals resulting from the sustainable source, is in high demand from the academic and industrial perspectives. coredata.dc:description: The current study focuses on the synthesis of an inexpensive, efficient, and cost-effective zirconium phosphate (ZrP) and its application in the one-step catalytic valorization of biomass-derived α-Pinene oxide (APO) into trans-Carveol (TC), which is used in the fragrance industry to produce essence oil. Amorphous zirconium phosphate (ZrP) with different P/Zr molar ratios (0.6–2.4) were synthesized using a simple (refluxing) method by controlling the concentration of dopant. The presence of phosphate groups was confirmed by FTIR and XPS analysis. The phosphate functionality provides the Brønsted acidic nature, and the acidity of the catalyst (ZrP3) is 0.9 mmol/g as measured by NH3-TPD analysis. Under optimized reaction conditions, the synthesized Brønsted acid catalyst (ZrP3) was used to valorize APO, resulting in complete conversion with 76% selectivity towards TC. The catalyst was recovered, activated, and reused numerous times with slight loss of activity or selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Chemoselective isomerization of α-Pinene oxide to trans-Carveol by robust and mild Brønsted acidic zirconium phosphate catalyst
